article.description: Chuck Davis scored 18 points and he gave Alabama its first lead with 3:46 remaining in overtime of a 72-68 comeback victory at Arkansas Wednesday.
article.headline: Alabama took first lead in OT
article.linkText: Alabama rallies from 22 down, tips Hogs in OT
article.story: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- Alabama ruined a Senior Night sendoff for one of Arkansas' toughest players Wednesday night. Charles Tatum hadn't started since a 2002 trip to Kentucky when Nolan Richardson was still the coach, but he started and hit three 3-pointers to help Arkansas take a 15-point halftime lead over the Crimson Tide. The Razorbacks pushed the lead to 41-19 in the second half before giving it and the game away, 72-68, in overtime. "We were playing so well, that you don't stop to see them coming back," said Tatum, who battled back to playing shape this year after missing a season because he tore three ligaments in his right knee during a pickup game. "We would get three and they would get five points. Next thing you know the lead is down. "We played a good 33 minutes and then Alabama is back in it. It's just bitter losing a game like this in the last game here as a senior." The Crimson Tide's comeback puts it in good shape to qualify for an at-large bid to the NCAA tournament. Alabama (16-10, 8-7 Southeastern Conference) has won four in a row and five out of six since ending a five-game mid-season losing streak on Feb. 14. "I would think this certainly shows that we're a team that ought to go (to the tournament)," Alabama coach Mark Gottfried said. "What a win and what a phenomenal comeback in a place like this." The win also gives the Crimson Tide a 4-4 record on the road in the SEC. "I think it's a great accomplishment," Gottfried said. "Our league is so tough. We're a team that's real young and I think they have surprised all of us." The victory guarantees Alabama a .500 record in the SEC going into the season finale at home against Mississippi State on Saturday. The Crimson Tide beat the fifth-ranked Bulldogs on Feb. 21. Chuck Davis scored 18 points and he gave Alabama its first lead with 3:46 remaining in overtime and Emmett Thomas' 3-pointer with 3:24 remaining made it a five-point lead. Arkansas (12-14, 4-11) tied the game at 68 after a 3-pointer by Eric Ferguson and a layup by Jonathon Modica, who finished with 17 points. Kennedy Winston hit the eventual game-winner, a 15-foot jumper with 28.5 seconds remaining for a 70-68 lead, while Davis and Thomas each made a free throw after Arkansas missed 3-pointers. The Crimson Tide chipped away at a 22-point deficit in the second half until Antoine Pettway sent the game into overtime tied at 63 with a 3-pointer over Ronnie Brewer's outstretched hands with 8 seconds remaining. "We had Pettway covered and it went in," Arkansas coach Stan Heath said. Winston scored 12 of his 17 points in the second half, while Davis had 11 during the half as Alabama fought back to send the game into overtime. Arkansas had a chance to win at the end of regulation, but Modica missed a wild shot at the buzzer. The loss means the Razorbacks have to win at Mississippi on Saturday and a couple of games at the SEC tournament to finish .500 and qualify for the NIT. "We got away from what we were working on in the second half," said Ronnie Brewer, who finished with 12 points, seven rebounds and five assists. "We had the game in our hands." Winston scored 12 points in the first 12 minutes of the second half and Earnest Shelton's five free throws in two trips cut the Razorbacks' lead to 56-49 with 7:33 remaining. Arkansas' offense had become stagnant. Modica hit a 3-pointer with 12:24 remaining to give the Razorbacks a 48-30 lead, but no one else scored over the next 11 minutes while Alabama tied the game. Modica scored 15 straight points until Olu Famutimi made a free throw with 39 seconds remaining. "(Modica) is a tremendous scorer and he has a knack to make some shots," Heath said. "Then the tendency is we do tend to stand around and watch and we do become a one-man oriented team." Modica didn't score in the first half, but he didn't need to because of Tatum. Tatum scored nine of his points on 3-pointers, matching his total production from the previous 12 games. His third 3-pointer countered one by Winston that pulled Alabama within 21-17. Arkansas had made just 2-of-25 3-pointers in a loss to Florida last Saturday, so the Crimson Tide came out in a zone defense. Tatum's shooting pulled Alabama out of the zone. Arkansas built a 34-19 halftime lead with a 10-2 run over the final 6:50 of the first half. Brewer and Matt Jones each had four points during the run and all 10 points were scored in the lane. Alabama clamped down on Arkansas in the lane after halftime, allowing just 10 points in the paint in the second half and overtime. "We didn't come out ready to play and Arkansas did," Winston said. "We had to come out with a lot more intensity in the second half to come out with a win. I feel pretty good about winning here tonight."
